mainmatter.p: If \Gamma \vdash e: \tauΓ⊢e:τ\Gamma \vdash e: \tauΓ⊢e:τ then e \to _{ \beta }^*e'e→β∗e′e \to _{ \beta }^*e'e→β∗​e′ for a normal form e'e′e'e′. And we can define subject reduction, if \Gamma \vdash e: \tauΓ⊢e:τ\Gamma \vdash e: \tauΓ⊢e:τ and e \to _{ \beta }e'e→βe′e \to _{ \beta }e'e→β​e′ then \Gamma \vdash e': \tauΓ⊢e′:τ\Gamma \vdash e': \tauΓ⊢e′:τ.

frontmatter.title: Simply Typed Lambda Calculus and Representation Theorems

mainmatter.p: We have explored the power of lambda calculus. Church's original purpose of the pure calculus of functions was a new foundations of mathematics distinct from set theory. Unfortunately the original lambda calculus is inconsistent (Every proposition has a proof). Church returned to the ideas by Russell and Whitehead and developed the Church's Simple Theory of Types. SLTC is a typed interpretation of the lambda calculus with only one type constructor \to→\to→ that builds function types.

We follow the converntion that function type constructor \to→\to→ is right-associative. We write e: \taue:τe: \taue:τ if expression eeee has type \tauτ\tauτ. \lambda x.x: \tau \to \tau λx.x:τ→τ \lambda x.x: \tau \to \tau λx.x:τ→τ But the type is not unique. The booleans can be typed: \begin {align*} \text {true} &= \lambda x. \lambda y.x : \alpha \to ( \beta \to \alpha ) \\ \text {false} &= \lambda x. \lambda y.y : \alpha \to ( \beta \to \beta ) \end {align*} true=λx.λy.x:α→(β→α)false=λx.λy.y:α→(β→β) \begin {align*} \text {true} &= \lambda x. \lambda y.x : \alpha \to ( \beta \to \alpha ) \\ \text {false} &= \lambda x. \lambda y.y : \alpha \to ( \beta \to \beta ) \end {align*} truefalse​=λx.λy.x:α→(β→α)=λx.λy.y:α→(β→β)​

frontmatter.title: Simply Typed Lambda Calculus and Representation Theorems › Typing Judgment

mainmatter.p: Wem can formalize judgments about expressions and types using inference rules. For instance: \frac { e_1: \tau _1 \quad e_2: \tau _2 }{ e_1 \space e_2: \tau _2 } e1:τ1e2:τ2e1 e2:τ2 \frac { e_1: \tau _1 \quad e_2: \tau _2 }{ e_1 \space e_2: \tau _2 } e1​ e2​:τ2​e1​:τ1​e2​:τ2​​ The application e_1 \space e_2e1 e2e_1 \space e_2e1​ e2​ has type \tau _2τ2\tau _2τ2​ if e_1e1e_1e1​ has type \tau _1 \to \tau _2τ1→τ2\tau _1 \to \tau _2τ1​→τ2​ and e_2e2e_2e2​ has type \tau _1τ1\tau _1τ1​.

We can record the types of variable in a typing context. \Gamma : \equiv x_1: \tau _1, \ldots ,x_n: \tau _n Γ:≡x1:τ1,…,xn:τn \Gamma : \equiv x_1: \tau _1, \ldots ,x_n: \tau _n Γ:≡x1​:τ1​,…,xn​:τn​ And we always assume that all variables declared in a context are distinct. This avoids any ambiguity when we try to determine the type of a variable. The typing judgment now becomes \Gamma \vdash e: \tau Γ⊢e:τ \Gamma \vdash e: \tau Γ⊢e:τ

frontmatter.title: Simply Typed Lambda Calculus and Representation Theorems › The Limits of Simple Types

mainmatter.p: Are there expressions that cannot be typed in the simple type system? Yes, for example, \Omega = \lambda x.x \space xΩ=λx.x x\Omega = \lambda x.x \space xΩ=λx.x x cannot be typed. But how do we prove that \OmegaΩ\OmegaΩ cannot be typed?

We can apply the typing rules and get a contradiction. \OmegaΩ\OmegaΩ is a lambda abstraction hence we can assume that it has type \tau \to \sigmaτ→σ\tau \to \sigmaτ→σ. Then xxxx has type \tauτ\tauτ and x \space xx xx \space xx x has type \sigmaσ\sigmaσ. By the application of x \space xx xx \space xx x we get that \tau = \tau \to \sigmaτ=τ→σ\tau = \tau \to \sigmaτ=τ→σ, which does not exist.

To recover from this in full generality we need recursive types. \tau =F \tau τ=Fτ \tau =F \tau τ=Fτ where F= \lambda \alpha . \alpha \to \sigmaF=λα.α→σF= \lambda \alpha . \alpha \to \sigmaF=λα.α→σ and we might have a solution with \tau =Y \space Fτ=Y F\tau =Y \space Fτ=Y F. But such solution is not available to us. We do not have function from types to types FFFF and a type level Y combinator. However it is ok to construct recursive types (we would do later).

frontmatter.title: Simply Typed Lambda Calculus and Representation Theorems › Characterizing the Booleans

mainmatter.p: We now show that the representation of the booleans is correct.

If \emptyset \vdash e: \alpha \to ( \alpha \to \alpha )∅⊢e:α→(α→α)\emptyset \vdash e: \alpha \to ( \alpha \to \alpha )∅⊢e:α→(α→α) and eeee is a normal form, then e = \text {true}e=truee = \text {true}e=true or e = \text {false}e=falsee = \text {false}e=false.
We will later combine this with the following theorems which yields correctness of the representation of the booleans.

If \Gamma \vdash e: \tauΓ⊢e:τ\Gamma \vdash e: \tauΓ⊢e:τ then e \to _{ \beta }^*e'e→β∗e′e \to _{ \beta }^*e'e→β∗​e′ for a normal form e'e′e'e′. And we can define subject reduction, if \Gamma \vdash e: \tauΓ⊢e:τ\Gamma \vdash e: \tauΓ⊢e:τ and e \to _{ \beta }e'e→βe′e \to _{ \beta }e'e→β​e′ then \Gamma \vdash e': \tauΓ⊢e′:τ\Gamma \vdash e': \tauΓ⊢e′:τ.

frontmatter.title: Simply Typed Lambda Calculus and Representation Theorems › Reduction revised

mainmatter.p: Our characterization of normal forms is quite simple: terms that do not reduce. However, this is a negative condition, which is difficult to work with in proofs. We would like to have a positive condition, which is easier to work with.

We tend to give definitions in the form of inference rules. The property then holds if the judgment can be derived using the rules. (This closely related to the inductive deefintion). Before defining the normal forms we formally define beta reduction. The judgment here e \to e'e→e′e \to e'e→e′ expressing that eeee reduces to e'e′e'e′. \begin {align*} \frac {}{( \lambda x.e_1)e_2 \to e_1[x:=e_2]} ( \text {red/beta}) \\ \frac {e \to e'}{ \lambda x.e \to \lambda x.e'} ( \text {red/lam}) \\ \frac {e_1 \to e_1'}{e_1 \space e_2 \to e_1' \space e_2} ( \text {red/app}_1) \\ \frac {e_2 \to e_2'}{e_1 \space e_2 \to e_1 \space e_2'} ( \text {red/app}_2) \end {align*} (λx.e1)e2→e1[x:=e2](red/beta)e→e′λx.e→λx.e′(red/lam)e1→e1′e1 e2→e1′ e2(red/app1)e2→e2′e1 e2→e1 e2′(red/app2) \begin {align*} \frac {}{( \lambda x.e_1)e_2 \to e_1[x:=e_2]} ( \text {red/beta}) \\ \frac {e \to e'}{ \lambda x.e \to \lambda x.e'} ( \text {red/lam}) \\ \frac {e_1 \to e_1'}{e_1 \space e_2 \to e_1' \space e_2} ( \text {red/app}_1) \\ \frac {e_2 \to e_2'}{e_1 \space e_2 \to e_1 \space e_2'} ( \text {red/app}_2) \end {align*} (λx.e1​)e2​→e1​[x:=e2​]​(red/beta)λx.e→λx.e′e→e′​(red/lam)e1​ e2​→e1′​ e2​e1​→e1′​​(red/app1​)e1​ e2​→e1​ e2′​e2​→e2′​​(red/app2​)​

A normal form is an expression that does not reduce. To give a proper formalization,, we need a separate judgment for neutral terms which do not create a redex when applied to an argument. \begin {align*} \frac {e \text { normal} }{ \lambda x.e \text { normal} } ( \text {normal/lam}) \\ \frac {e \text { neutral} }{e \text { normal} } ( \text {normal/var}) \\ \frac {}{x \text { neutral} } ( \text {neutral/var}) \\ \frac {e_1 \text { neutral} \quad e_2 \text { normal} }{e_1 \space e_2 \text { neutral} } ( \text {neutral/app}) \\ \end {align*} e normalλx.e normal(normal/lam)e neutrale normal(normal/var)x neutral(neutral/var)e1 neutrale2 normale1 e2 neutral(neutral/app) \begin {align*} \frac {e \text { normal} }{ \lambda x.e \text { normal} } ( \text {normal/lam}) \\ \frac {e \text { neutral} }{e \text { normal} } ( \text {normal/var}) \\ \frac {}{x \text { neutral} } ( \text {neutral/var}) \\ \frac {e_1 \text { neutral} \quad e_2 \text { normal} }{e_1 \space e_2 \text { neutral} } ( \text {neutral/app}) \\ \end {align*} λx.e normale normal​(normal/lam)e normale neutral​(normal/var)x neutral​(neutral/var)e1​ e2​ neutrale1​ neutrale2​ normal​(neutral/app)​

frontmatter.title: Simply Typed Lambda Calculus and Representation Theorems › Normal Forms and Reduction

mainmatter.p: The characterization of normal forms via inference rules is compact, but is it really the same as saying that an expression does not reduce? We break this down into the following two properties. For all expressions eeee, either eeee reduces or eeee is normal For all expressions eeee, it is not that case eeee reduces and eeee is normal
We have theorem that ensures that the first property holds. (Proof is omitted).
For every expression eeee, either e \to e'e→e′e \to e'e→e′ for some expression e'e′e'e′ or eeee is a normal form.
